#Text=CHAPTER XIII
#Text=For three days I did my own work and Thomas Mugridge ’s too ; and I flatter myself that I did his work well .
#Text=I know that it won Wolf Larsen ’s approval , while the sailors beamed with satisfaction during the brief time my régime lasted .
#Text=“ The first clean bite since I come aboard , ” Harrison said to me at the galley door , as he returned the dinner pots and pans from the forecastle .
#Text=“ Somehow Tommy ’s grub always tastes of grease , stale grease , and I reckon he ai n’t changed his shirt since he left ’ Frisco . ”
#Text=“ I know he has n’t , ” I answered .
#Text=“ And I ’ll bet he sleeps in it , ” Harrison added .
#Text=“ And you wo n’t lose , ” I agreed .
#Text=“ The same shirt , and he has n’t had it off once in all this time . ”
#Text=But three days was all Wolf Larsen allowed him in which to recover from the effects of the beating .
#Text=On the fourth day , lame and sore , scarcely able to see , so closed were his eyes , he was haled from his bunk by the nape of the neck and set to his duty .
#Text=He sniffled and wept , but Wolf Larsen was pitiless .
#Text=“ And see that you serve no more slops , ” was his parting injunction .
#Text=“ No more grease and dirt , mind , and a clean shirt occasionally , or you ’ll get a tow over the side .
#Text=Understand ? ”
#Text=Thomas Mugridge crawled weakly across the galley floor , and a short lurch of the Ghost sent him staggering .

#Text=In attempting to recover himself , he reached for the iron railing which surrounded the stove and kept the pots from sliding off ; but he missed the railing , and his hand , with his weight behind it , landed squarely on the hot surface .
#Text=There was a sizzle and odour of burning flesh , and a sharp cry of pain .
#Text=“ Oh , Gawd , Gawd , wot ’ ave I done ? ” he wailed ; sitting down in the coal-box and nursing his new hurt by rocking back and forth . “ W’y ’ as all this come on me ?
#Text=It mykes me fair sick , it does , an ’ I try so ’ ard to go through life ’ armless an ’ ’ urtin ’ nobody . ”
#Text=The tears were running down his puffed and discoloured cheeks , and his face was drawn with pain .
#Text=A savage expression flitted across it .
#Text=“ Oh , ’ ow I ’ ate ’ im ! ’ Ow I ’ ate ’ im ! ” he gritted out .
#Text=“ Whom ? ”
#Text=I asked ; but the poor wretch was weeping again over his misfortunes .
#Text=Less difficult it was to guess whom he hated than whom he did not hate .
#Text=For I had come to see a malignant devil in him which impelled him to hate all the world .
#Text=I sometimes thought that he hated even himself , so grotesquely had life dealt with him , and so monstrously .
#Text=At such moments a great sympathy welled up within me , and I felt shame that I had ever joyed in his discomfiture or pain .
#Text=Life had been unfair to him .
#Text=It had played him a scurvy trick when it fashioned him into the thing he was , and it had played him scurvy tricks ever since .
#Text=What chance had he to be anything else than he was ?
#Text=And as though answering my unspoken thought , he wailed :

#Text=“ I never ’ ad no chance , not ’ arf a chance ! ’ Oo was there to send me to school , or put tommy in my ’ ungry belly , or wipe my bloody nose for me , w’en I was a kiddy ? ’ Oo ever did anything for me , heh ? ’ Oo , I s’y ? ”
#Text=“ Never mind , Tommy , ” I said , placing a soothing hand on his shoulder .
#Text=“ Cheer up .
#Text=It ’ll all come right in the end .
#Text=You ’ve long years before you , and you can make anything you please of yourself . ”
#Text=“ It ’s a lie ! a bloody lie ! ” he shouted in my face , flinging off the hand .
#Text=“ It ’s a lie , and you know it .
#Text=I ’m already myde , an ’ myde out of leavin ’s an ’ scraps .
#Text=It ’s all right for you , ’ Ump .
#Text=You was born a gentleman .
#Text=You never knew wot it was to go ’ ungry , to cry yerself asleep with yer little belly gnawin ’ an ’ gnawin ’ , like a rat inside yer .
#Text=It car n’t come right .
#Text=If I was President of the United Stytes to-morrer , ’ ow would it fill my belly for one time w’en I was a kiddy and it went empty ?
#Text=“ ’
#Text=Ow could it , I s’y ?
#Text=I was born to sufferin ’ and sorrer .
#Text=I ’ve had more cruel sufferin ’ than any ten men , I ’ ave .
#Text=I ’ve been in orspital arf my bleedin ’ life .
#Text=I ’ve ’ ad the fever in Aspinwall , in ’ Avana , in New Orleans .
#Text=I near died of the scurvy and was rotten with it six months in Barbadoes .
#Text=Smallpox in ’ Onolulu , two broken legs in Shanghai , pnuemonia in Unalaska , three busted ribs an ’ my insides all twisted in ’ Frisco . An ’ ’ ere I am now .
#Text=Look at me ! Look at me !
#Text=My ribs kicked loose from my back again .
#Text=I ’ll be coughin ’ blood before eyght bells . ’
#Text=Ow can it be myde up to me , I arsk ? ’ Oo ’s goin ’ to do it ? Gawd ? ’ Ow Gawd must ’ ave ’ ated me w’en ’ e signed me on for a voyage in this bloomin ’ world of ’ is ! ”
#Text=This tirade against destiny went on for an hour or more , and then he buckled to his work , limping and groaning , and in his eyes a great hatred for all created things .
#Text=His diagnosis was correct , however , for he was seized with occasional sicknesses , during which he vomited blood and suffered great pain .
#Text=And as he said , it seemed God hated him too much to let him die , for he ultimately grew better and waxed more malignant than ever .
